2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: How Did the Economy Get Here?
2024.summary: President Tom Barkin explores where the U.S. economy is today, how it got here and where it may be headed.

2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: Recognizing the Impact of Community Colleges
2024.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses what community colleges (and the Richmond Fed) are doing to strengthen the skilled trades talent pipeline.

2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: Why Not Declare Victory?
2024.summary: President Tom Barkin shares his views on the economy and the recent rate cut, and then looks to what could come next.

2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: Why Were Forecasts Off?
2024.summary: President Tom Barkin explores why it has been particularly challenging to predict the path of the economy over the last few years.

2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: Navigating Data Whiplash
2024.summary: President Tom Barkin reflects on recent data and shares his view on where the U.S. economy is headed.

2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: How You Might Look at Recent Data
2024.summary: President Tom Barkin explores different ways to look at recent data, and then gives his own perspective.

2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: Inflation: Handle With Care
2024.summary: Recent data have been remarkable. President Tom Barkin shares why he still sees reasons for caution.

2024.speaker: Tom Barkin
2024.title: Heading for a Soft Landing?
2024.summary: President Tom Barkin reflects on 2023 and shares his outlook for the year ahead.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: The Housing Challenge
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin shares how communities in the Fifth District are working to move the needle on housing.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: What’s Next for the Economy?
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin explores potential paths for the U.S. economy and their implications for monetary policy.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: Looking Beyond Recent Data
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses what he is hearing on the ground from Fifth District contacts, and how it compares to recent data.

2023.speaker: Kartik Athreya
2023.title: Learning from (Banking) Failure
2023.summary: At the Killinger Lecture held by Iowa State University's Economic Club, Research Director Kartik Athreya discussed the 2023 bank failures and the broader banking and regulatory issues they raised.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: The New Job Hierarchy
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin explores what’s happening in the labor market and how it could impact the path ahead.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: Recession Revisited
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses what’s driving the resilient U.S. economy and where it may be headed next.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: The Inflation Story
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin explores a plausible story for how inflation returns to target.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: Bringing Talent to Small Towns
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin shares how small towns in the Fifth District are putting their best foot forward to attract talent.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: The Need to Be Nimble
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses recent data and events and explores potential implications for monetary policy.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: What’s Keeping Inflation Elevated?
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses how he sees the economy, and the implications for inflation and for policy.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: 2023 Economic Outlook
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin reflects on monetary policy and the economy in 2022 and shares his thoughts on what’s ahead.

2023.speaker: Kartik Athreya
2023.title: Inflation in the Economy: Getting Here, and Looking Ahead
2023.summary: The past few years have seen unprecedented real economy shocks, which are particularly hard to deal with for any central bank, and so drove a lot of the inflation in the wake of the pandemic's arrival.

2023.speaker: Tom Barkin
2023.title: Learning from Our Community
2023.summary: President Tom Barkin shares how engagements with the Fifth District community inform our understanding of the economy.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: Is a Labor Challenge Coming?
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin explores whether labor will continue to be in short supply, and what that could mean for the U.S. economy.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: The Evolution of Technological Disruption
2022.summary: President Barkin reflects on the relationship between technological innovation, the economy and monetary policy.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: What’s Driving Inflation?
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin considers the forces behind today’s high inflation and offers his outlook for the economy.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: The Staffing Challenge in Schools and Caregiving
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin explores some of the crucial segments lagging behind in the jobs recovery.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: Winning the War on Inflation
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin outlines how he expects inflation to come down.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: The Recession Question
2022.summary: As the Fed works to contain inflation, many ask whether we are headed into a recession. President Barkin shares his perspective.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: Rethinking the Office
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses how firms can optimize the hybrid work environment.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: Why We Care About Inflation
2022.summary: Inflation hasn’t been a hot topic for decades. Now that it’s back, it’s clear consumers and businesses dislike it. Richmond Fed President Tom Barkin discusses why and how the Fed is working to contain it.

2022.speaker: Kartik Athreya
2022.title: Our Differences Matter: Heterogeneity in Macroeconomic Analysis
2022.summary: Research Director Kartik Athreya discussed economic disparities and the implications for households, researchers and policymakers.

2022.title: Beyond Today’s Inflation Storm
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin explores the conditions we may face once we navigate through the current inflation storm.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: A Unique Moment for Small Towns
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses pools of funding available to small towns, the barriers these communities face in accessing funding, and explores potential solutions to these barriers.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: Containing Inflation
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses how the Federal Reserve is working to contain inflation and reflects on the post-pandemic era economy.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: Breaking Down the Labor Shortage
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses how the labor shortage story differs across key segments of the economy.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: Investing in Rural America
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses critical investments to support rural economic development.

2022.speaker: Tom Barkin
2022.title: The Economy: What We’ve Learned
2022.summary: President Tom Barkin reflects on lessons learned last year and looks forward at what this year could look like for the U.S. economy.

2021.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses the factors keeping workers out of the labor force—and how employers are responding.

2021.summary: President Tom Barkin shares his perspective on recent economic data and the outlook for inflation.

2021.summary: President Tom Barkin discusses the factors influencing wage growth in the wake of the pandemic.

2021.summary: Richmond Fed Research Director Kartik Athreya spoke about the importance of understanding economic decision making by older adults.

2021.title: On Remote Work, Markets Will Decide
2021.summary: The market will decide the future of remote work, says President Tom Barkin in his latest essay.This essay appears in the May issue of Econ Focus magazine.

2021.speaker: Tom Barkin
2021.title: The Last Mile for Stimulus
2021.summary: What does it take to deliver funding the “last mile” to the people who need it? Read more in President Tom Barkin’s latest essay.

2021.summary: President Tom Barkin spoke about investments to help address long-term disparities exposed by COVID-19.

2021.summary: President Tom Barkin spoke about the potential for COVID-19 to leave long-lasting scars on the economy—and how policy can help.

2021.summary: President Tom Barkin talks about the pandemic’s lasting influence on office life.

2004.speaker: Jeffrey M. Lacker
2004.title: Economic Outlook
2004.summary: Richmond Fed President Jeffrey M. Lacker spoke December 20, 2004 at the  Charlotte Chamber of Commerce Annual Economic Outlook Conference in Charlotte, N.C.

2004.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2004.title: Comments on the Economy and Monetary Policy
2004.summary: As usual I’ll begin with a recap of recent developments in the economy to put the outlook in perspective. Then I’ll comment on the outlook — as others see it and I see it — and finally I’ll conclude with a few remarks about monetary policy.

2004.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2004.title: VCU School of Business Commencement
2004.summary: Dean Sesnowitz; distinguished members of the faculty; proud parents and other family members; guests; and, of course most importantly, members of the Virginia Commonwealth University School of Business Class of 2004: thank you for your welcome and the privilege of sharing a few reflections with you this afternoon on this very special occasion.

2004.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2004.title: Comments on the Economy and Banking
2004.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you this morning, and I am honored by your invitation to address this Convention once again. When Jack Benny was honored in some way back during his career, he said he didn't deserve the honor.

2004.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2004.title: Hampden-Sydney College Commencement
2004.summary: President Bortz; distinguished members of the faculty and board of trustees; proud, satisfied — and probably relieved — parents; guests; and — most importantly, of course — members of the Hampden-Sydney Class of 2004: thank you for your welcome and for the privilege of joining you on this memorable day.

2004.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2004.title: Competition in Banking: Achieving the Right Balance
2004.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you this morning. The theme of this session is “How Banks Compete.” I want to develop a variation on this theme and consider how the intensity of competition in banking has increased over the years, and some of the challenges this change presents.

2004.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2004.title: The Economic Outlook for 2004
2004.summary: It's a pleasure to be back with you once again. I don't know exactly how many years you've honored me by inviting me back, but it's an appreciable number, and I always enjoy being with you. I guess I should say most of the time.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: Macroeconomic Principles and Monetary Policy
2003.summary: It's a great pleasure and honor for me to be invited to participate in this Forum, although I have to tell you that I was more than a little intimidated when I learned that I would be part of a panel featuring Bob King and Tom Sargent.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: Attack at the Economic Heart of America: What 9/11 Taught the United States about Its Economic Security
2003.summary: It's a great pleasure and honor for me to be invited to participate in this Forum, although I have to tell you that I was more than a little intimidated when I learned that I would be part of a panel featuring Bob King and Tom Sargent.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: The Economy: Where is it Headed and When?
2003.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you this evening, and a pleasure to serve as Longwood's Executive-in-Residence earlier today.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: Update on the Economy and Monetary Policy
2003.summary: These remarks update other recent speeches Mr. Broaddus has made regarding the U.S. economic outlook.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: Remarks on the Economy and Monetary Policy
2003.summary: It is a pleasure to be back with you once again. I'm truly honored that you invite me back so frequently, although I'm reminded of something that Jack Benny said once when he received an award of some sort.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: Remarks at the 13th Annual Hyman P. Minsky Conference on the State of the U.S. and World Economies
2003.summary: And certainly the extraordinary difficulty currently in trying to discern U.S. macroeconomic prospects for the next year or so is not inconsistent with Twain's observation.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: The Economic Outlook in a Turbulent Period
2003.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you today, although I have to confess that I am not very alert because I had a nightmare last night.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: The Economic Outlook for 2003
2003.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you today. Each year I receive several invitations to give talks on the economic outlook for the year ahead, and this is my first such talk for 2003.

2003.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2003.title: Comments on Monetary Policy in a Low Inflation Environment
2003.summary: It's a pleasure to be here today and to have this opportunity to comment on conducting monetary policy in a low inflation environment.

2001.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2001.title: Transparency in the Practice of Monetary Policy
2001.summary: This has been a very useful conference in my view, and I am honored by this opportunity to be a part of it.1 As some of you may know, I was the second choice for this slot, but that doesn't bother me at all because the first choice was Don Brash, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and a pathbreaker in bringing both transparency and accountability to central banking in practice.

2001.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2001.title: Housing as an Economic Development Tool
2001.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you this evening. Most of the speeches I make deal with national economic outlook and Fed monetary policy, and it is refreshing to have an opportunity to talk about something else.

2001.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2001.title: Moving up, Moving Forward, and Moving Out
2001.summary: Thank you very much. Ms. Roberson, members of the faculty, parents and friends, and — most importantly — members of the Thomas Jefferson High School Class of 2001, it is truly a pleasure and an honor to be with you this afternoon.

2000.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2000.title: Current Challenges for U.S. Monetary Policy
2000.summary: It is a pleasure and an honor to be invited to participate in this conference.

2000.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2000.title: Market Discipline and Fed Lending
2000.summary: It's a pleasure to address this Conference once again.

2000.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
2000.title: An Overview of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act and Brief Remarks on the Economy
2000.summary: It has been a while since I had the pleasure of speaking to this group, and I've been looking forward to this dinner.

1999.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1999.title: Incentives and Banking
1999.summary: It's a pleasure to be with you tonight. Bryce has welcomed you on behalf of the Powell Endowment.

1999.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1999.title: EMU and the Role of the National Central Banks in the Eurosystem
1999.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you tonight here at Davidson. I have counted a number of Davidson alumni as good friends and colleagues over the years, but for some reason this is the first opportunity I have had to visit the Davidson campus. I am happy to have the chance to do so this evening even though I have to make a speech to earn it!

1998.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1998.title: The Bank Merger Wave: Causes and Consequences
1998.summary: I'm delighted to be here today to talk with you about the wave of bank mergers that is sweeping across our country-our hometown included.

1997.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1997.title: Longwood College Commencement Address
1997.summary: President Cormier, distinguished members of the faculty, graduates, families and friends.

1997.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1997.title: Collaborative Community Development: Creating Linkages for the Future
1997.summary: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for joining us here in Baltimore to discuss community economic development.

1997.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1997.title: The Economy: New Paradigm or Old Paradigm?
1997.summary: Ladies and gentlemen, it is a pleasure to be with you today for your 11th Annual Business Expo.

1997.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1997.title: Reflections on Community Banking
1997.summary: It is a pleasure to be with you today, and I thank you for inviting me.

1997.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1997.title: Economic Education: Making the Half-Truths Whole
1997.summary: Ladies and gentlemen, it is a pleasure and a privilege to address you today, both for professional and personal reasons.

1996.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1996.title: U.S. Monetary Policy: Looking Back to Find the Future
1996.summary: Needless to say, it's a great pleasure for both Margaret and me to have this opportunity to return to IU, where we spent four very happy years between mid-1966 and mid-1970.

1995.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1995.title: Reflections on Monetary Policy
1995.summary: Mr. Broaddus wishes to thank his long-time colleague, Timothy Cook, for substantial assistance in preparing the address.

1993.speaker: J. Alfred Broaddus
1993.title: Central Banking: Then and Now
1993.summary: Thank you very much for that kind introduction. It is very nice indeed to be here in the Shenandoah Valley.
